Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Exascale Formal Verification Algorithms for Parameterized Probabilistic Models of Complex Computational Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project creates high-performance algorithms for discovering and validating parameterized probabilistic models against formal specifications of their expected behavior. Probabilistic models naturally describe the impact of uncertainties on the behavior of many real-world systems including probabilistically correct computing devices, autonomous cyber-physical systems, and multi-outcome predictive models. Parameters in computational models are employed to represent incompleteness in the knowledge about the system being described - either due to a lack of sufficient experimental insight or due to the need for constructing template designs that can be reused. The analysis and synthesis techniques for probabilistic systems developed in this project could have a broad impact since many important real-world systems are probabilistic in nature.

The project exploits the synergy between Bayesian risk analysis and change of probability measures to design new model validation algorithms that expose rare but interesting behaviors of computational models. By leveraging theoretical results in randomized metric embeddings and practical advances in extreme-scale computing, the project creates new parallel algorithms for synthesizing parameters of probabilistic models from a suite of behavioral specifications. The project uses computational models of biochemical and cyber-physical systems as benchmarks for evaluation, and creates a web-based cyber-infrastructure for rapid dissemination of the algorithms to the wider community. The project will accelerate the design of complex predictive models by automatically validating them against multiple historical observations. It will also enable a formal methods based uncertainty quantification framework for analyzing the correctness of intelligent cyber-physical systems - thereby, making these devices safer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project studied new algorithms for discovering and validating probabilistic models against specifications of their expected correct behavior. Probabilistic models naturally describe the impact of uncertainties on the behavior of many real-world systems, including autonomous cyber-physical systems, biochemical models, and artificial intelligence (AI) models.  

The intellectual merit contributions of the project include (i) algorithms for high-assurance AI and cyber-physical systems and (ii) discovering parameterized biochemical models from specifications. We have created new algorithms for developing confidence metrics in responses of AI systems that can be used even when we do not have access to all of the training data or access to a held-out validation data set. A confidence metric in the response of an AI system can be measured by sampling the neighborhood of an input but such an estimation of confidence becomes exponentially challenging as the dimension of the input increases. Our confidence metric computation exploits feature concentration observed in many AI systems and uses an attribution-based sampling approach over the features to compute the confidence metric.

We have created a testing approach for intelligent cyber-physical systems (CPS). Systematic testing of such intelligent CPS is a challenge due to the exponential state space associated with their high-resolution visual and other sensory inputs. Our approach demonstrates how fuzzing the input using patterns obtained from a convolution neural network can be used to test such intelligent CPS. 

We have created parameter discovery algorithms for synthesizing parameters of complex stochastic models of biochemical systems from one or more temporal logic specifications. Our approach uses a combination of Bayesian hypothesis testing and simulated annealing to algorithmically compute parameters of proabilistic models, and we have applied this approach to models from biology.

The broader impacts of the project include novel algorithms for designing high-assurance AI and autonomous cyber-physical systems and validating intelligent CPS against functional correctness specifications. The parameter discovery algorithms are likely to make an impact on the rapid design of computational models in biology and other domains. The project has successfully supported the training of PhD students and undergraduate researchers.
